quoteLast: the positions were entered and captured, the Artillery lifting on to the reverse slopes.

quoteFirst: “I must shut up for the night at nine,” said the jailer, “and it's now
quoteLast: .” He placed the little candle on a rough pine table, and withdrew.
title: The Pioneers; Or, The Sources of the Susquehanna

title: Round the World in Eighty Days
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Frith, Henry, 1840- [Translator]

quoteFirst: Well named from its mercurial habits, having the smallest orbit, and being the most rapid traveler, presents in a given time more phases than any other of the planets. Thus we find that on the 3d, at 5:00 p. m., it is in inferior conjunction with the sun, that is, between the earth and the sun; on the 14th, at
quoteLast: , 2° 1′ south of the moon; on the 14th, at 3:00 p. m., stationary, that is, it is moving in a direct line (or nearly so) away from the earth, and thus _seems_ to stand still; on the 24th, at 5:00 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, January 1885, No. 4
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

title: Around the World in Eighty Days. Junior Deluxe Edition
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: The General, he had his breakfast at 8:45 A.M. to the tick. He might have been a Long Island commuter. At
quoteLast: I’d go down to the Thirty-fourth Street ferry to meet him—I mean I’d see the Zigler into position at two thousand (I began at three thousand, but that was cold and distant)—and blow him off to two full hoppers—eighteen rounds—just as they were bringing in his coffee.
title: Traffics and Discoveries
author: Kipling, Rudyard, 1865-1936
